titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: This day, Mr. Richard I Morsell called on me with his Son, and made me the Annual payment, of three-hundred dollars, due this day, according to our agreement offor the purchase of the House which I purchased of Daniel Baker, and he also paid in advance the remaining Sum of one hundred and one dollars and fifty-five cents, which would be due, on the first of April 1848. to complete the final payment, deducting therefrom six dollars and ten cents, being the interest, which would be due, on the sum remaining to be paid, as the final payment, on the first of April next The whole sum that I received from him this day therefore was three-hundred and ninety-four dollars, and sixty five cents; for which I gave a receipt in full, and am now to give him, a Deed in Fee of the House—

I made a draft, of a Deed in Fee, to Richard I. Morsell, of the House which I purchased of the Revd. Daniel Baker— I received a Letter, from Milnor Rudulph, of Memphis Tennessee, dated 15th. March 1847. Yesterday I received, a Letter, signed H. Holtz Chairman, being a mock account of a meeting of Planters, at Dancyville Tennessee and of certain ridiculous resolutions, passed at that meeting, to be forwarded to me, with the request, that I would urge the immediate interference, in their behalf— I rose this day, more unwell than I have been for several months, and sent for Dr. Thomas, who ordered new prescriptions for me to take, and I took a morning ride in the Carriage, with Elizabeth. C Adams, and Mrs. John— After which, I found myself somewhat better— I sent also to Mr. Alexander Borland the Carpenter, and directed him to make, several boxes, to Ship the Cargo Folio News papers in Volumes, for my residence at Quincy— I had some other business to attend to, but postponed it, as it was, Good Friday—

Ezra R. Keefer for Charles Wilson Commission Merchant at Alexandria brought me a Certificate signed by . . . Mantz. Treasurer of Frederick City Hotel. dated the 26th. of March 1846, that there appears from the Books of the Frederick City Hotel to be thirty two dollars, and fifty cents standing to the credit of John Adams, for Dividends due, to which certificate is subjoined, a note in the following words—A power of Attorney, and a simple order to transfer, is all that is necessary the order to be in favour of Michael Zimmerman I had agreed, with Mr. Wilson, to transfer the five Shares, for one hundred and fifty dollars, and thirty two dollars and fifty cents, for the Dividends standing due thereon— I accordingly drew up a Power of Attorney, to Michael Zimmerman, authorizing him to make the transfer and received, from Mr. Keefer, for Mr. Charles Wilson, a check on the Potomac Bank at Alexandria, for one-hundred and eighty-two dollars and fifty cents payable to me, on my Order—

Easter Sunday— I attended at Saint Johns Church, morning and afternoon, and heard Mr. Pyne, read the Services of the day, and preach from both parts of the day from Colossians, 3.1. “If ye then be risen with Christ seek those things which are above, where Christ sitteth on the right hand of God”— After the afternoon service, I rode in the carriage, with Elizabeth. C. Adams, and Mrs. John Adams, into Georgetown— Mr. and Mrs. Frye were here part of the evening.

This morning I executed the power of Attorney, to Michael Zimmerman, to transfer the five shares, in the Frederick City Hotel, standing in the name of my deceased son John, and delivered the same to Ezra R. Keefer, for Charles Wilson, Commission Merchant at
Alexandria—and I deposited in the Bank of the Metropolis, the check on the Bank of Potomac at Alexandria, which was there received and entered to my credit as cash— The papers relating to this transaction are placed, among my bundle of Deeds and Vouchers—

I, this day, and my wife executed and acknowledged, before two Justices of the Peace for the County of Washington, and District of Columbia, Sam D King, and A Tho Smith, a Deed in fee, to Richard. I. Morsell, of the Estate, which I purchased, of Revd. Daniel Baker, and I delivered the Deed of the same to the said Richard. I. Morsell. keeping a copy of the same Deed and of its acknowledgement, which I put upon file among my deeds and vouchers—

List of Deeds, and other private Vouchers. belonging to John Quincy Adams. kept in a separate Bundle, at Washington—tied up in a calico cover—together, with a copy of the last Will, of the said John Quincy Adams, executed at Boston, on the 18th. of January last, another copy of which, is in the possession, of Charles. Francis. Adams, constituted Sole Executor of the said Will—

list.item: No. 1. Will of J. Q. Adams— 18th. January 1847—

div.p: Mary Louisa being unwell this day, our Diary was suspended—as also the list of Private Deeds and Vouchers—
We resumed today, the list of Deeds and Vouchers—

I attended in the morning Divine Service at the Unitarian Church—where Mr. Longfellow preached. from Phillippians 3.13. “But this one thing I do, forgetting those things which are behind, and reaching forth, unto those things which are before. 14. I press toward the mark,”— In the afternoon, at St. Johns Church, I heard Mr. Tillinghast from Providence Rhode Island read the prayers for the first Sunday after Easter and preach from Luke 2.14. “Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace good will towards men.” A sermon, with which I was greatly pleased, being the song of the Angels at the Birth of Jesus. the most wonderful, the most sublime, and the most cheering passage, in the Holy Scriptures. After the Afternoon Service, I took a ride with Mrs. John Adams and Elizabeth, and Mary Louisa. We passed the evening without visitors. The news was received of the surrender of the City of Vera Cruz and the Castle of St. Juan D’Ulloa to the American Army on the 27th. of March under the command of General Winfield Scott—

Visit this morning from Phillip R. Fendall Esq. We continue to take minutes, of Deeds and Vouchers, for preservation. Last evening about ten there was a fire in our neighborhood, in the house occupied by. and this morning about eight oclock there was an other in the house nearly opposite ours, on the other side of the street. belonging to Joseph Abbott and occupied by Mr. Heiss, one of the Editors of the Union newspaper— They were both extinguished with out much damage. Received from my son, Charles F. Adams, a draft from L. M. Stone Cashier of the Merchants Bank at Boston, payable at one days sight, without grace, for one thousand two hundred dollars, endorsed payable to Richard Smith, Cashier of the Bank of Metropolis, and this day taken up by me— This Bill, was to pay, for five shares, in the stock of the Old Massachusetts Bank. in Boston invested in the name of Mrs. Mary Catherine Adams, my daughter— Received by her, in
exchange for 1000 dollars, of Washington City Corporation six per cent Stock, standing in my name, but belonging to her. and also, for five shares in the Frederick City Hotel, which stood in the name of her husband deceased, but which I as his Administrator, recently sold, for one hundred and eighty two fifty cents. The two sums, amounting to 1182 dollars, and fifty cents, leaving a balance of 40 dollars, charged to me, by my Son, in his account— The Letter from my Son, and the draft taken up by me are placed among my private Vouchers.

I took to the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions a Letter from Wm. Ellis of Dedham of the 18th. February last relating to the Claims, of John Endicott, and others, and of Peter Dunbar— Also a Letter from Elisha. G. Tucker, Boston 26th. February last, on the Claim of the widow of J. B. Brereton. Also the Letter of Jason Holbrook Randolph, 25th. February 1847, relating to the claim of the heirs of Ichabod Holbrook, for commutation Pay and Bounty Lands. Also the Letter of Wm. K. Hoyt, no. 24. Mc.Dougal Street, New York, 16th. February 1847, and the Letter of Jonathan Wild, of Braintree, 12th. April 1847. relating to the Claim of Deborah Wild for a pension.

I have received from George. H. Colton, a Letter dated the 3d. New York, enclosed with which, was an Article, for the next Number of his American Review upon Executive patronage and National expenditure Upon which he requests, remarks from me— I answered the Letter of George. H. Colton, with remarks on the Article. respecting the power of removing Public Officers—

Mary Louisa went with a party to Baltimore, to see the Viennoise dancers. morning ride to the Clerks Office of the House at the Capitol. Afternoon walk. Evening visit, from Mr. Abbott and Mr. Longfellow preacher at the Unitarian Church.

Mrs. John Adams received a message from her daughter Mary Louisa at Baltimore not to expect her home this day— No morning walk— Received a Bill of lading for eight boxes of books and papers, shipped at Georgetown, in the Schooner May E. A. Nickerson Master by John. Q. Adams, Quincy to be delivered to Charles. F. Adams, Boston— Paid check 114. Bank of the Metropolis, to Haslup and Weeden $28.87 also check 115. to T. F. Semmes $23.50 cents for a fifteen gallon Cask of Madeira wine— Afternoon ride—Mr. Larned and Miss Elizabeth Johnson were here this evening

Lieut Joseph H. Adams, here— Arrived in the Levant, from the Pacific at Norfolk. Virginia— Mary Louisa returned from Baltimore— Mrs. William. B. Kibby and Mrs. George Parker came for a contribution for the Protestant Orphan Asylum— Mr Frye was here this evening and left with me, a Letter from me, to him, dated the 28th. November 1837. stating that the Deeds of the Columbian
Mills were then missing from the Bundle—

I went to the Pension Office, with a certificate from J. G. Palfrey Secretary of State of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, dated February 1844—attesting the service of Peter Dunbar from 29th. July 1780. to 11th. of August 1780—which exactly completed the six months, and Mr. Edwards said, he would make out the certificate— I went to the Franklin Insurance Company Office, where I was informed, that there are no meetings of the Stockholders, but that there will be a meeting of the Directors of the Company a Committee of whom will report to them, a statement of the affairs of the Company, and the half yearly Dividend to be made on Monday next, 3d. of May I took the list of the Directors at the present time. Election is held, the first week in June—

Mr. Parkman son of George Parkman of Boston was here. Lieut Joseph. H. Adams left us, to return to his Ship the Levant, at Norfolk Virginia. His brother Isaac Hull Adams, went with him. Mary Louisa, went with Mr. James Buchanan the Secretary of State, to the President and Mrs. Polk’s reception evening Party—
